docs.snippet: Michele McEvoy, a pintsized 18-year-old senior at Summit (N. J.) high school, will represent the United States in the junior international jumping competition starting next Thursday in San Juan, P. R.
docs.lead_paragraph: Michele McEvoy, a pintsized 18-year-old senior at Summit (N. J.) high school, will represent the United States in the junior international jumping competition starting next Thursday in San Juan, P. R.

headline.main: Miss McEvoy Set for Jumper Event

docs.snippet: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 16 -- Regis Debray, a French exponent of Marxist revolution in Latin America, left for Cuba today carrying a manuscript of a study he has prepared on Socialist prospects in Chile under President Salvador Allende Gossens.
docs.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 16 -- Regis Debray, a French exponent of Marxist revolution in Latin America, left for Cuba today carrying a manuscript of a study he has prepared on Socialist prospects in Chile under President Salvador Allende Gossens.
docs.abstract: Debray, in Chile since Dec 22, leaves for Cuba with study of Pres Allende's regime

headline.main: Debray Leaves Chile for Cuba With Study of Allende Regime

byline.original: By JUAN de ONISSpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 19 -Argentina's smoldering guerrilla war has been fought in recent months on an increasingly bloody scale, and guerrilla incidents are occurring at the rate of about one a day, with bands taking over entire towns for brief periods.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 19 -Argentina's smoldering guerrilla war has been fought in recent months on an increasingly bloody scale, and guerrilla incidents are occurring at the rate of about one a day, with bands taking over entire towns for brief periods.
docs.abstract: guerrillas intensify drive, taking over towns in Cordoba and BA for brief periods and creating incidents with increasing frequency; recent devastating raid on BA hosp stirs fear guerrillas are ready to launch large attacks, including bombing and shooting of mil installations, US businesses and homes; experts are unable to explain expansion of activities, fear impact of Marxist Chilean Govt and Uruguayan Tupamaros; guerrilla groups listed; illus

headline.main: Argentine Guerrillas Step Up Drive; Experts Foresee Big-Scale Attacks

byline.original: By MALCOLM W. BROWNESpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Gomide's release awaited at end of 40-day suspension of const guarantees, as has been promised by Tupamaros
docs.abstract: Gomide's release awaited at end of 40-day suspension of const guarantees, as has been promised by Tupamaros

docs.snippet: A second letter purporting to be from the urban guerrillas who kidnapped Dr. Claude L. Fly, a United States agricultural expert, in Uruguay last Aug. 7 was received here yesterday.
docs.lead_paragraph: A second letter purporting to be from the urban guerrillas who kidnapped Dr. Claude L. Fly, a United States agricultural expert, in Uruguay last Aug. 7 was received here yesterday.
docs.abstract: Purported Tupamaro lr recd by NY Times sec C R Hulsart reiterates demand made in Jan for $1-million as ransom for kidnapped Amer Dr Fly; bears handwritten message from him to Mrs Fly, apparently asking her to accept demand; postscript illus; Hulsart says he could find no reason why lr was sent him; lr demands that reply be pub in NY Times; makes no ref to other Brazilian captive A Gomide

headline.main: New Letter Demands a $1-Million Ransom for Dr. Fly

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- The kidnapped Brazilian consul, Aloysio Dias Gomide, was freed tonight after more than six months of captivity after his wife, Maria, paid a ransom to the leftist Tupamaro guerrillas.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- The kidnapped Brazilian consul, Aloysio Dias Gomide, was freed tonight after more than six months of captivity after his wife, Maria, paid a ransom to the leftist Tupamaro guerrillas.
docs.abstract: Gomide freed after 6-mo captivity following payment of ransom by Mrs Gomide who raised money in fund-raising tour of Brazil and reptdly conducted secret talks with Tupamaros; looks tired, says he is 'a little seasick' and bothered by light; Brazilian Embassy says Gomide was set free at countryhome on outskirts of Montevideo, picked up by embassy car and taken to home of embassy official; Feb 12 Tupamaro statement says Mrs Gomide has paid ransom and that Gomide will remain freed after Govt restores full const rights; repts of ransom paid range from $250,000 to $1-million; Pres Pacheco earlier tried, but failed, to get Cong to extend security decree; Tupamaros say Brit Amb Jackson and Fly are in 'people's prison'

headline.main: Uruguay Leftists Free Brazilian Aide for Ransom

docs.snippet: MUNICH, West Germany -- Within the last five years 800 movie theaters closed in West Germany. The phenomenon is not exclusively German, of course; what is exceptional, however, is the artistic poverty of the pictures shown in German movie houses.
docs.lead_paragraph: MUNICH, West Germany -- Within the last five years 800 movie theaters closed in West Germany. The phenomenon is not exclusively German, of course; what is exceptional, however, is the artistic poverty of the pictures shown in German movie houses.
docs.abstract: F Bondy article on arts scene; illus

headline.main: Munich: The Decline of Cinematic Art

byline.original: By FRANCOIS BONDYSpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Mrs. Claude L. Fly, the wife of a United States agricultural expert kidnapped in Uruguay last Aug. 7, said yesterday that a handwritten postscript to a purported ransom note "does not look like my husband's handwriting."
docs.lead_paragraph: Mrs. Claude L. Fly, the wife of a United States agricultural expert kidnapped in Uruguay last Aug. 7, said yesterday that a handwritten postscript to a purported ransom note "does not look like my husband's handwriting."
docs.abstract: Mrs Fly doubts handwriting on lr is his, statement read by son J Fly by telephone; her por

headline.main: Wife Doubts Guerrillas' Captive In Uruguay Signed Latest Note

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 27 -- Leftist journalists, whose efforts to publish a daily newspaper in Uruguay have been regularly thwarted by the Government, announced plans this week to attempt publication of a new newspaper.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 27 -- Leftist journalists, whose efforts to publish a daily newspaper in Uruguay have been regularly thwarted by the Government, announced plans this week to attempt publication of a new newspaper.
docs.abstract: Journalists plan new leftist daily which will support candidate from leftist coalition known as Frente Amplia, and replace leftist daily closed earlier in mo by Pres Pacheco with Cong opposition; move spurs as yet unresolved disagreement between exec and legis powers; Pacheco's increasingly stern controls over press criticized by liberals and IAPA; he reptdly objects to various leftist newsmen he considers tacitly friendly to Tupamaros; Argentine Pres Levingston's talks with Pacheco earlier in wk, on terrorism and other issues, boycotted by newsmen after authorities arrested, later released, Argentine reporter for asking directions to conf

headline.main: Defiant Newsmen in Uruguay Plan New Leftist Daily
